Yes, I think we are still experiencing the effects of the changes introduced by the Reformation in modern-day religious practices. The Reformation created a shift toward an individual's responsibility and freedom in interpreting religious texts and developing their own spiritual beliefs. This shift away from traditional religious hierarchies continues to impact Christian denominations today.

For example, in many Protestant churches, individual Bible study and interpretation are still highly valued, and congregations often emphasize individual spiritual growth and personal relationship with God. The idea that believers can have a direct relationship with God without the need for priestly mediators continues to hold sway to this day.

Moreover, the Reformation also influenced the development of non-Christian religions, which also placed greater emphasis on spiritual individualism and individual interpretation. The shift toward individualism and away from traditional authority structures also contributed to the development of new religious movements outside of traditional religious institutions.

Lastly, world events such as globalization, scientific advancements, and increasing secularization have contributed to the ongoing transformation of religious belief and practices. These changes have continued to emphasize the importance of personal responsibility and spiritual independence, which are legacies of the Reformation.
